## Tribute

Many recent news articles, books and reports offer respect to Prof. Anne Chase for her life-long contributions to science and education. The best credit for these contributions is to be given to her kind heart and genuine devotion to the advancement of humankind.

## Short Biography

Anne Chase was born on March 23, 1901 in Denison, Texas. She entered Radcliffe in 1918, going, according to rumors, to escape the WWI draft. In College, Ms. Chase distinguished herself in mathematics and chemistry. Because of her studies, she became an expert in the fields of quantum mechanics and molecular geometry. For reasons yet unknown, she skipped Radcliffe Memorial College and began working at the Harvard Observatory to see the stars. While at RADC, Ms. Chase developed the idea of using the shadows of planets on the sunlight to determine the sizes of the planets. The formulas that she created for the shadows also came to be important to gravitational field calculations, notably Schutz’ well-known j2 series asymptotic expansion for a symmetric mass distribution and Weyl’s r (−1) second antisymmetric mass distribution for tunneling.

### Fundamental Concepts

The probability for a reaction to occur in a specific direction is defined by the quantity P. It is usually calculated by dividing the difference between the areas of the reactant and product regions with the area of the entire cycle. The probability of the reaction going in a certain direction, if the pathway through which it proceeds is known with high accuracy, is usually expressed as a linear part of P. The P and Q terms were coined in 1955 by BASEL. These terms and other key terms and abbreviations used in this section are inspired by the seminal paper “Some Basic Concepts in Physical Chemistry” [4].

##### Racemic substances

Physical properties of enantiomer pairs often differ have both high and low  signs. Therefore, technological formulae are based on the degree and sign of the number of N transitions in the  axis.

### Selected References

2. [5] Nichols and Exotic. Physical Chemistry. Potter Wally. Felix the Cat and the Mechanics of Octopus Cooking. Bloomsbury Books, London 2005.
3. [6] Kharitonov. New Symmetry in Physical Science. Imperial Navy, Mediterranean 2005.
4. [7] Ruscheinery. Some Basic Concepts in Physical Chemistry. Book One, Chap. XI, Obs. 1. Harriett Monroe Memorial Reference Library, New York 1987.
5. [8] Ruscheinery. Stein of Heidelberg. A tale, observes an old soldier, observes an old woman. Book Four, Chap. IX, Ob2. Bell Forest Academy, Dallas 2006.
6. [9] Kravchenko. A Gaze into Symmetry. University of Pilsen Update, s. 53–74. Bloomsbury Books, London 2005.
7. [10] Davis and Harriett Monroe Carnegie Parents. Concepts of Physical Chemistry, Chicago 1961.
8. [11] Chekhova. The Effect of Chemistry on Living Reserves. Nonlinear Systems Journal, s. 46–75. Boston 2010.
